node.title: Trump says he got the booster shot and dismisses fans who boo him
node.description: The former president tried to correct a smattering of boos in the audience.
node.content: ["Washington \u2013 Former President Donald Trump received his COVID-19 booster shot, he told supporters during an event in Dallas on Sunday. Hearing some boos in the audience, the ex-president dismissed them, according to video posted to social media.\u00a0", "Trump revealed his booster status during a conversation with former Fox News host Bill O'Reilly, telling the host \"yes\" when asked if he received the booster shot. O'Reilly continued the conversation, but Trump interjected when he heard some in the crowd booing his answer.\u00a0", "\"Don't, don't, don't, don't, don't, no, no. That's \u2014 there's a very tiny group over there,\" the former president said in response to an apparent smattering of boos, according to video posted by O'Reilly's show \"No Spin News.\"\u00a0", "Prior to the question about the booster, Mr. Trump lauded his administration's efforts to develop the three COVID-19 vaccines authorized for use in the U.S., saying \"we did something historic\" and urging supporters to \"take credit \u2014 we saved tens of millions of lives.\"", "The former president was criticized for not disclosing his vaccination status while in office, in contrast to former Vice President Mike Pence and other top officials. Pence and others received the vaccine on camera, something Trump declined to do. Only in March did news outlets learn Trump was vaccinated at the White House in January, and many in his own party wanted him to be more consistently vocal in support of the vaccine.\u00a0", "The vaccine was developed while Trump was in office, and its production supported by Operation Warp Speed. But Republicans have been more hesitant to get vaccinated, according to CBS News and other polling.", "Of American adults who are fully vaccinated, only roughly 30% have received a booster shot, according to the Centers for Disease Control.\u00a0", "Kathryn Watson is a politics reporter for CBS News Digital based in Washington, D.C."]
